name: Kepler-160
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-160 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-160 is a star with 1.1539999999999997 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.12 times its radius. It is located 3140.62 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-160 is known to have 3 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-160 b

Kepler-160 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.06 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 4.31 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-160.

The mass of Kepler-160 b is 3.51 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-160 b is 1.715 that of Earth. At 3.51 Earth masses, Kepler-160 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-160 c

Kepler-160 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.12 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 13.70 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-160.

The mass of Kepler-160 c is 23.03 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-160 c is 3.76 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, Kepler-160 c is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.

Kepler-160 d

Kepler-160 d was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit timing variations method. Its discovery was announced in 2020-06. Its semi-major axis is 0.17 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 30.00 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-160.

The mass of Kepler-160 d is 99.99 times the mass of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, Kepler-160 d is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-160, which contains 3 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
